sect1.title: Introduction
sect1.para: This document is intended to provide all you need to collaborate with us in XPde development. This is an open document, so if you feel there is something missing, don't hesitate to contact us.

sect1.title: Your account
sect1.para: As a part of the team, you will get the following:

listitem.para: An @xpde.com mail account, you must setup your mail client with the following data:
user: yourlogin%xpde.com
pass: the one you provided
POP,SMTP: mail.xpde.com

This account will be subscribed to the mailing list development@xpde.com, it's encouraged you read this mail list, this is the main method we use for communication, but if you need to unsubscribe, send a mail to development-unsubscribe@xpde.com to be removed.
You also will be added to the Team page, along with your photo, your role on the team and a short paragraph about you
You will be also subscribed to http://dcl.xpde.com, a ticketing system we are starting to use to manage the projet, it will be useful when the team gets larger
You can also subscribe to http://bugs.xpde.com to report bugs and contact with us to update your access level to developer if you want to be able to fix bugs.

sect1.title: Getting the sources and building
sect1.para: In the documents directory, you can find a buildguide, this guide explains how to get the sources from the CVS, how to get Kylix Open Edition and how to rebuild the sources. You can also rebuild XPde by using Ant, check out the build.xml file.

sect1.title: CVS
sect1.para: To submit your changes and collaborate with other members in this project, you will need to use CVS, don't worry about that, it's a very simple system and if you have never used it, we bet you will think it's great. You can find all this information in the documents directory, on the CVS guide.

sect1.title: Resources
sect1.para: As a team we have a list of resources we use, for source code, for communication, etc:

listitem.para: Main Page (http://www.xpde.com)
This is the main page of the project, it's the central repository of resources and news, this must be your first stop
Project Page (http://developer.berlios.de/projects/xpde)
We host our project on BerliOS, the system they use it's the same than SourceForge, we only use their CVS server
CVS repository (http://cvs.berlios.de/cgi-bin/viewcvs.cgi/xpde/)
To browse the source code, you can use the Browse CVS option at the project page
Bug tracking (http://bugs.xpde.com)
This is the bug tracking tool we use, it's a Mantis, you will need to subscribe yourself to report bugs and also tell us to be updated as developer and be able to fix bugs
Ticketing (http://dcl.xpde.com)

This is a system to manage work on a team, to send tickets to each other requesting for work, or simply a common place to setup things to do, right now it's not very useful due the current size of the team, but it will become very important in a near future.
IRC Channel (irc://irc.freenode.net/xpde)
Forums (http://www.xpde.com/modules.php?name=Forums)

Users can post their questions here, right now post is only allowed to registered users, maybe this change in a future. At the bottom you can find a private forum for the team, contact with us to get the password.
FAQ (http://www.xpde.com/modules.php?name=FAQ)
Here you can find a FAQ, it's nice to read it to know what to answer in the forums to give support to users
Team page (http://www.xpde.com/modules.php?name=Team)
This is the XPde team, we are listed in joining order
Mailing List (mailto:development-subscribe@xpde.com)
This is our main way to communicate, right now there is only one list, this will grow in the future

sect1.title: Coding guidelines
sect1.para: It is very important to use some coding guidelines when developing in a collaborative project like this, the code must be as clearer as possible and every member must be able to read it. We are not talking about design patterns, but a coding style to make all source code look the same. This guidelines are not closed, and we, as Delphi developers, we have a very similar coding style. All this is explained in a separate document, called coding guidelines, but it's not finished yet.

sect1.title: Form design
sect1.para: In this project we have little space for innovation on form design, we have a model on Windows XP which we must follow to-the-pixel-point, but in any other case, where the Windows XP dialogs are not what we must use in Linux, we must follow some common rules. Also, this is nice to allow another team members to edit our forms. To let our forms integrate with the rest of the desktop and to react to user changes on desktop and appearance properties, we must use the XPstyle unit, a Kylix/Qt style which changes all the way our widgets look. Also we need to set the Scaled properties of all our forms to false and the ParentFont to true.

sect1.title: Document creation
sect1.para: If you need to create documents to be shared with another members or published to the users, we are using DocBook as publishing platform, this system is based on XML and allows to write the document and publish it on many formats including PDF, HTML, PS, TXT, etc. You can also use XXE, from XMLMinds as editor, it's made in Java and provides CSS rendering for DocBook documents, so it's just like a word processor.
